['King James VI/I - The first monarch to rule over both England and Scotland, becoming the patron of Scotland after uniting the two nations through the Union of Crowns in 1603.', 'Queen Elizabeth II - As the current reigning queen of the United Kingdom, she is the present-day patron of numerous Scottish organizations and events.', "Sir Walter Scott - A famous Scottish novelist who was knighted by King George IV for his literary contributions to Scotland's culture, he became a symbolic patron for Scottish literature.", 'Robert Burns - Known as the national poet of Scotland, celebrated for his poems and songs that often depicted daily life in Scotland, Burns is seen as a cultural patron.', 'Sir Walter Elliot - A character from Jane Austen\'s "Persuasion," he was initially portrayed as an idealistic patron who supported the arts and literature but later revealed to be somewhat misguided.', 'Queen Anne - The queen of Scotland, wife of King William II, known for supporting Scottish culture through her encouragement of the arts and music.', 'Mary Queen of Scots - As a monarch, she patronized many noble families in Scotland, fostering political alliances that helped secure her reign over Scotland before becoming queen consort to France.', 'Sir Alexander Montgomery - A Scottish nobleman who became an advocate for the arts and letters during his lifetime, helping support cultural development in Scotland.', 'George Buchanan - A Protestant scholar, poet, and political writer who was a patron of education and learning in Scotland during the 16th century.', 'Robert Bruce - King of Scots who fought for Scottish independence from England; he is revered as a national hero and symbolic patron of freedom and Scottish identity.', "Mary, Queen of Scots' Patronage - Throughout her reign, she supported religious institutions like the Reformed Church in Scotland and promoted education by founding schools.", 'King James IV of Scotland - He was a supporter of the arts, music, and literature, as well as an advocate for Scottish culture and identity during his rule.', 'Sir John Edmond Hope - A military commander who became patron to several charitable institutions in Scotland, including the Royal Hospital Kilmainham, which helped support Scottish soldiers.', 'King Alexander III of Scotland - His reign marked a period of cultural growth for Scotland, and he was considered an important patron of arts and music during his time.', "Robert Crawford - A Scottish poet whose literary works celebrated the beauty of Scotland's landscape and heritage, making him a symbolic patron of Scottish poetry.", "King James V of Scotland - Patronized several cultural institutions in Scotland including Edinburgh's Holyrood Abbey; he also supported the development of Scottish music and dance.", 'Patrick Geddes - A renowned Scottish sociologist, philosopher, ecologist, and pioneer in town and regional planning, who is considered a patron of modern urbanism and environmental preservation in Scotland.', "Mary, Queen of Scots' Patronage (cont.) - She was also known for her support of charitable causes such as hospitals, orphanages, and schools throughout Scotland.", 'King David II of Scotland - During his reign from 1329 to 1371, he supported various religious institutions in Scotland, making him a significant patron of the Catholic Church during this period.', 'Patrick Hamilton - A Scottish Protestant reformer who was instrumental in establishing schools and seminaries in Scotland, advocating for education as a vital part of cultural development in the country.']

['Sonnet - A poetic form consisting of fourteen lines with specific rhyme schemes and meter, usually expressing love or passion.', 'Haiku - A traditional Japanese three-line poem (5-7-5 syllable pattern) that often captures a moment in nature.', 'Villanelle - A 19-line poetic form consisting of five tercets and one quatrain, with the first and third lines of the opening stanza repeated alternately as the final line of each subsequent tercet and both repeated again at the end of the poem.', 'Limerick - A humorous five-line poem with a specific rhyme scheme (AABBA) and anapestic meter, often containing witty or nonsensical content.', 'Ode - An elaborately structured lyric poem that praises something or expresses deep emotion about a subject, usually in the form of four to seven stanzas with a varied rhyme scheme.', 'Ballad - A narrative poem set to music and typically written in quatrains (four-line verses), often recounting folk tales or stories from history.', 'Sestina - A complex, six-stanza poetic form with intricate repetition of end words, consisting of three sestets followed by a tercet envoi.', 'Ghazal - An Arabic and Persian poetic form composed of couplets that share a rhyme scheme and an interrelated refrain, usually exploring love or spirituality.', 'Concrete Hexameter - A modern poetic structure consisting of six lines with seven syllables per line and specific internal patterns of stress.', 'Blank Verse - Unrhymed iambic pentameter verse used in English poetry, often employed to express serious or dramatic subject matter.', 'Epigram - A brief, witty poem that usually presents a clever observation about human nature and is often satirical in tone.', "Spenserian Stanza - An intricate, interlocking stanza form consisting of nine lines with the rhyme scheme ABABBCBCCA; the final line (C) also ends with an internal rhyme using the preceding B-line's last word.", 'Acrostic - A poem or phrase in which certain letters in each line, starting from a particular point (usually the first), form a word, message, or summary related to the subject of the poem.', 'Ghazal - An Arabic and Persian poetic form composed of couplets that share a rhyme scheme and an interrelated refrain, usually exploring love or spirituality.', 'Villanelle - A 19-line poetic form consisting of five tercets (three-lined stanzas) followed by one quatrain (four-line stanza), with specific repeating end words in a unique pattern.', 'Ode - An elaborate, lyrical poem that typically addresses and celebrates an individual subject or idea through praise and admiration.', 'Haibun - A Japanese literary form combining prose and haiku poetry to convey personal thoughts or stories while also incorporating vivid imagery in the poetic elements.']

['Avoidance - The act of keeping away from or not engaging with something.', 'Steer Clear - To go around, avoiding something closely.', 'Eschew - Deliberately avoid using or abstain from something.', 'Shun - To persistently avoid or reject someone/something.', 'Elude - Escape skillfully, especially under challenging circumstances.', 'Evade - Skillfully escape or avoid (an obstacle or danger).', 'Sidestep - Move to the side in order to avoid something.', 'Dodge - Quickly move out of the way by using rapid steps and/or sudden changes in direction.', 'Bypass - To pass over, go around, or avoid (something) particularly a difficult part.', 'Elude - Avoid by cleverness; escape from clutches; evade.', 'Refrain - Hold oneself back or abstain from an action.', 'Disengage - Move away in space, distance, time, etc., especially with the intention of avoiding involvement.', 'Diverge - To turn aside from a direction or course; to go in different directions.', 'Skirt Around - To talk about something indirectly instead of addressing it directly and plainly.', 'Shun Away - Move away quickly and suddenly, as if to avoid someone or something.', 'Dodge Attention - Be deliberately unnoticed or ignored.', 'Escape Unscathed - To leave a situation without any harm or damage.', 'Skirt Past - Move swiftly around the periphery of an area, often to avoid detection.', 'Evade Questions - Avoid giving direct answers and deliberately not responding to inquiries.', 'Remain Clear Of: To stay away from or be free from confusion, doubt, or uncertainty.']
